question: How did the relationship between Rudolph and Mrs. Forrester develop during their time together at the Flowery Pagoda, particularly when Mrs. Forrester expressed regret to Rudolph and he observed her flushed and radiant as she concluded a narrative with a droll pantomime?
gold_answer: At the Flowery Pagoda, Mrs. Forrester expressed regret to Rudolph, and he saw her flushed and radiant as she ended a narrative with a droll pantomime.
llm_answer:
The evidence shows that, during their time at the Flowery Pagoda, Mrs. Forrester’s manner toward Rudolph becomes more open and kindly.  
When she greets him she speaks “graciously,” gives “a look more natural, more sincere, than she had ever given him,” and says she has “heard so much about you.”  
A little later, standing alone with him on the pagoda, she rests her hand on his arm and says, “I was sorry. I thought of you so often,” showing explicit regret.  
At the very moment she expresses this regret, Rudolph observes her “flushed and radiant” as she finishes a comic story with “a droll pantomime,” the same scene in which she first greets him.  

Thus, within this single episode the relationship shifts from distant formality to one of warmer, more personal sympathy on her side, and of heightened, confused feeling on his.
